column1: We just cancelled our third international trip, and cannot wait to return to the TCI. As much as we'd love to go tomorrow, we want the Islanders to be as safe and protected as possible, and support the Government's decision to keep the borders closed.A lot of the Regular Posters on this Forum own condos, villas, businesses, etc. They should know... Have any of the Resorts instituted a Special Assessment to cover the additional costs that will be necessary to keep everyone safe? The Resorts should be planning and collecting supplies now. Many people have standing reservations and/or credits/vouchers, and many others will be afraid to travel internationally for a while, so raising prices isn't going to work. Resorts and Businesses on all of the Islands are going to have to invest significant resources to ensure to guests that their businesses and properties are safe.We have given this a lot of thought and think Resorts, Businesses, Restaurants and the Government should do all of the following: 1) Encourage Social Distancing -- keep guests/patrons at least 6 feet apart from others whenever possible2) Move all loungers and chairs into the direct sun between uses and wipe them down with lysol or similar between uses3) Visitors should handle their own luggage at the airport, into and out of cabs and in to their rental units4) Resorts, Restaurants, Taxis should provide lysol or similar cleaning products in all rental units and in all locations so customers can wipe down chairs, handles, surfaces, etc themselves5) Restaurants should use disposable plates, glasses, napkins and utensils. This will cause a lot of waste (economic and environmental), but a $2.00 fee can be added to each entree to cover some of the purchase and disposal costs6) Resorts and all businesses should institute contactless payments wherever possible7) Resorts and all businesses should request that customers use their own pens OR provide brand new pens anytime something needs to be signed OR should disinfect pens with lysol or similar after each use8) Resorts should encourage minimal use of housekeeping. Towel exchanges should be made every 3rd day, at most. Almost all units have washers and dryers -- Resorts/Owners should ensure that there is enough detergent and other cleaning supplies 9) Mask use should be encouraged inside (in Airport, grocery store, etc.). Everyone should have a mask since airlines are requiring them10) Resorts should provide lysol wipes or similar for any shared resource bicycles, tennis rackets, etc11) The government should Eliminate/Postpone high density events like the Fish Fry12) Contactless thermometers should be used to take temperatures at the airport and before entering restaurants. If temperature is spiked, deny entry/quarantine -- as appropriate -- and lodging details need to be shared and someone needs to follow-up.If anyone else has thoughts or suggestions, please add to the list. If the above actions are taken, we think that people will slowly return. With 90 to 100 degree temperatures, and the beach as the draw, asking tourists to wear masks outdoors is not practical. And, yes, having to wear masks and needing to self-clean is no one's perfect, but we should all be used to it in our everyday lives by the time the island opens up and people may want to help the island economically and may be ready for a change of scenery.Stay and Travel safe! ;-)
